Después del fallecimiento del esposo de Concepción C., y con nueve hijos pequeños, Concepción comenzó a trabajar lavando y planchando ropa, y los fines de semana hacía tamales y vendía comidas, así fue buscando la prosperidad de sus hijos quienes ahora son personas que buscan por su independencia, sin embargo Concepción, está buscando ubicar un negocio frente a su casita para poder mantener sus necesidades, puesto que nunca contó con seguro social, hoy tiene que pagar todos los gastos de sus chequeos.

Por lo tanto Acude a usted para solicitar un crédito de $925 para pagar en un plazo de 6 meses para poder construir y amueblar su pequeño localito de comidas para que ella no se tenga que desplazar a otro lugar. Concepción desea seguir sintiéndose útil, por lo tanto está buscando este negocio, y así no tener que depender de algún hijo, puesto que cree que las fuerzas y ganas las tiene para emprender un nuevo negocio. Con tu ayuda Concepción, podrá hacer su sueño realidad.

loans.use: To build and furnish a business to sell food.

loans.name: Gloria De La Luz

texts.es:
Gloria Luz is a mother who thinks about her family's future. She has taken use of her cooking abilities to make dishes and sell them from her home. This has enabled her to pay rent and other expenses, since her husband is a mason and works on a temporary contract basis. Months have passed on without any work for him. Meanwhile, Gloria has slowly established her food business.

However, she still needs to grow to move forward with her family. Thus, she seeks a loan of $650, which she will pay back in installments over 6 months. The loan will be used to buy ingredients for her food and furniture. With your help, Gloria's children will be able to go to school without any financial burden.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Volunteer.

Gloria Luz, es una mujer que piensa en el futuro de su familia y en el de ella, puesto que aprovechando las habilidades que tiene para preparar alimentos, comenzó a vender comidas en su casa, y así poder solventar los gastos que se le presentasen en su hogar, ya que su esposo trabaja como albañil y ese negocio es de temporadas, es por ello que el salario que recibe no es fijo y pueden pasar meses sin trabajo que hacer. Poco a poco se ha ido estableciendo Gloria con su localito de comidas.

Sin embargo, necesita seguir creciendo para poder salir adelante, y por lo tanto hoy está solicitando un préstamo de US $650 para pagar en un plazo de 6 meses para poder adquirir materiales y mobiliario para elaborar sus comidas. Con tu ayuda los hijos de Gloria podrán salir de la escuela sin problemas económicos y así serán hombres de bien.

loans.use: To buy ingredients to make food

loans.name: Miriam

texts.es:
Miriam has a great passion for making clothes, which she also studied to learn more about this profession. Her passion has also enabled her to progress her marriage since her husband constantly was unemployed. Such is the case now as he has no dependable means of income. Previously, he worked as a security guard. Miriam works hard to make clothes for her neighbors and relatives. Today, she has various customers and works hard to keep them.

Currently, Miriam needs a loan of $650 to buy materials like fabric, thread, bows, buttons, elastics, etc., which will be used in making clothes. The loan will be paid off in installments over 6 months. She would like to provide better service for her customers. It is important that we support Miriam since she is the sole breadwinner for her family. Your help is very much appreciated.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Volunteer.

Miriam tiene una gran pasión que es la costura, de la cual decidió estudiar para aprender más sobre este oficio y es lo que saca adelante a su matrimonio puesto que su esposo de constantemente no tiene un trabajo, tal como es el caso actual que no cuenta con trabajo, y su antiguo empleo fue como guardia de seguridad. Miriam se dedica a coser para sus vecinas y familiares, hoy tiene ya varios clientes que son los que ella trata de conservar.

Hoy Miriam necesita un préstamo de US $ 650 para pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses para poder comprar materiales tales como; telas, hilos, listones, cierres, botones, elásticos, etc. que le permitan elaborar sus trabajos y darle una mejor atención a sus clientes. Es muy importante que apoyen a Miriam puesto que es el único ingreso que tiene esta familia para sobrevivir. Muchas gracias por tu ayuda.

loans.use: Buy materials to make clothes

loans.name: Fidelina

texts.es:
Hello, my name is Fidelina S.. I have a small restaurant in the small area called El Chile which I have had for 3 years. I make breakfast, lunch and dinner. I have great clientele because there are a few schools near me as well as offices which make up a large part of the orders I get.

At this time, I need three blenders and a small freezer because I would now like to provide my customers with shakes and smoothies.

With the money from my profits I help put my two sons through school, being that I am a single mother. My eldest son is in college and the youngest is in school. I want my children to graduate so they may have a better life. I thank you in advance for your help.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva volunteer Wendy Wise

Hola, mi nombre es Fidelina S. tengo un pequeño restaurante de venta de comida en la Colonia el Chile hace 3 años. Yo vendo desayunos, almuerzos y cena , tengo una buena cliente porque tengo serca esculas y oficinas y me hacen varios pedidos. En estos momentos necesito comprar 3 licuadoras y un friser pequeño ya que quiero vender tambien licuados de frutas. Con los ingresos que me genera el negocio yo le pago los estudios a mis dos hijos ya que soy madre soltera, mi hijo mayor estudia en el colegio, y el menor esta en la escuela. Yo quiero que mis hijos se graduen para que puedan tener una mejor vida. Les agradesco mucho por su ayuda.

loans.use: Purchase blenders, glasses and a small freezer

loans.name: Ni Ketut Jepun

texts.id:
Living in Brawantangi village, West Bali, where all the inhabitants are Hindus, made Ni Ketut Jepun to be in the Banten (Hindu prayer Offerings made from young coconut leaves) business. Ni ketut Jepun makes Banten for ceremonies like Marriage; Nyambutin (ceremonies to celebrate child birth, after they are 3 months old; Ngotonin (ceremonies to celebrate child birth, after they are 1.5 years old). Ni ketut Jepun has 6 workers to help her, that are being paid Rp10,000-Rp15,000 (about $1-1.65)/day. With an initial capital of Rp500,000 (about US$55), Ni ketut Jepun bought raw materials to make Banten, like: young coconut leaves, bamboos, banana leaves, and assortment of flowers. Profit after subtracting labor cost and buying raw materials are Rp100,000 (about US$11). Every day Ni Ketut Jepun makes banten from 8:00AM - 5:00PM. Profit is used besides paying for daily expenses, are also used to pay for education expenses for her 4th grader daughter. Ni Ketut Jepun hopes that Dinari's loan could be used to increase capital, so that she could serve more customers. Ni Ketut Jepun plans to repair her hut, that is made from woven bamboo, and sand floor, to make it a more permanent home, worthy to live in.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Tinggal di Desa Brawantangi, Bali Barat, yang semua penduduknya beragama Hindu membuat Ni Ketut Jepun menekuni usaha Dagang Banten ( sarana untuk umat Hindu sembahyang yang terbuat dari daun kelapa muda ). Ni ketut Jepun membuat banten untuk upacara seperti pernikahan, untuk Nyambutin ( upacara untuk merayakan kelahiran anak. Dilakukan setelah anak berumur 3 bulan ) dan juga Ngotonin ( upacara untuk merayakan kelahiran anak setelah berumur 1,5 tahun ). Ni Ketut Jepun dibantu oleh 6 orang tenaga kerja yang dibayar dari Rp.10.000.- sampai Rp.15.000.- per hari. Dengan modal awal Rp. 500.000.- Ni Ketut Jepun membeli bahan baku untuk membuat banten seperti daun kelapa muda, bambu, daun pisang dan aneka jenis bunga. Keuntungan yang diperoleh setelah dikurangi untuk biaya tenaga kerja dan juga untuk pembelian bahan sebesar Rp.100.000. Ni Ketut Jepun setiap hari membuat banten dari jam 08.00 pagi sampai jam 05.00 sore hari . Keuntungan yang diperoleh selain untuk kebutuhan sehari – hari, dipakai juga untuk pendidikan satu putrinya yang sekarang duduk dikelas 4 SD. Ni Ketut Jepun berharap pinjaman yang diperoleh dari Dinari dipakai untuk menambah modal usahanya agar dapat melayani lebih banyak pelanggan. Ni Ketut Jepun berencana untuk memperbaiki rumahnya yang terbuat dari gedeg dan lantai tanah, menjadi rumah yang lebih permanen dan layak untuk ditempati.

loans.use:
To add capital to buy raw materials to make Banten, like: young coconut leaves, bamboos, banana leaves, and assortment of flowers

Menambah modal usaha untuk membeli bahan baku untuk membuat Banten seperti daun kelapa muda, bambu, daun pisang dan akeka jenis bunga

loans.name: Ni Luh Suryaningsih

texts.id:
Although a teacher's wife, Ni Luh Suryaningsih is definitely a persistent lady worker. Ni Luh Suryaningsih is helping her husband by opening a retail stall in her house. Besides economical needs, this business is worked on to help paying for education cost of her 9th grader child. With an initial capital of Rp 1,000,000 (about US$110), Ni Luh Suryaningsih sells various sales items, like light food, cold drinks, and also vegetables. Ni Luh Suryaningsih opens her stall in the moring 06:00 AM unitl evenings 6:00PM. In the afternoon, Ni Luh Suryaningsih is helped by her husband after coming home from work to wait for the stall, so that Ni Luh Suryaningsih could rest a while. Day's profit could reach up to Rp50,000 (about US$5.50). Ni Luh Suryaningsih hopes that Dinari's loan could be used as additonal capital of her business.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Walaupun sebagai istri seorang Guru, Ni Luh Suryaningsih memang seorang wanita yang ulet bekerja. Ni Luh Suryaningsih membantu suaminya dengan membuka usaha warung dirumahnya. Disamping untuk memenuhi kebutuhan ekonomi, usaha ini ditekuninya untuk membantu menambah biaya pendidikan anaknya yang sudah duduk di kelas 3 SMA. Dengan modal awal Rp.1.000.000,- Ni Luh Suryaningsih menjual berbagai macam dagangan seperti makanan ringan, roti, minuman dingin , dan juga sayur mayur. Ni Luh Suryaningsih mulai membuka warungnya dari pagi hari jam 06.00 sampai jam 06.00 sore hari. Kalau siang hari, Ni Luh Suryaningsih dibantu suaminya yang sudah pulang kerja untuk menjaga warungnya sehingga Ni Luh Suryaningsih bisa istirahat sebentar. Keuntungan yang diperoleh dalam satu hari sampai Rp. 50.000,-. Ni Luh Suryaningsih berharap pinjaman dari Dinari bisa dipakai sebagai modal untuk tambahan usahanya.

loans.use:
To add business capital

Menambah modal usaha

loans.name: Ni Luh Kasiantini

texts.id:
Ni Luh Kasiantini is a hardworking mother. After giving birth 4 months ago, Ni Luh Kasiantini besides looking after her baby, also opened a retail stall in her home. Every daily household items needs and vegetables are provided. Besides selling main staples, Ni Luh Kasiantini also sells pig's feed, like rice and wheat shell clippings and Konsentrat (local brand). With an initial capital of Rp 1,000,000 (about US$110), Ni Luh Kasiantini started her business. Daily profit could reach Rp50,000 (about $5.50). This profit is used to help her husband, I Komang Suwitra, who is in the cocoa seeds buying & selling business, to pay for daily expenses, and also for education for her 2 school age children, one in 4th grade, the other in kindergarten, while the last is a 4 month old baby. Ni Luh Kasiantini hopes that the with the capital to be obtained from Dinari, she could expand her business forwards. Her house is build on own land, and the building is quite permanent. Daily living expenses could reach Rp25,000 (about US$2.75)/day.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Ni Luh Kasiantini seorang Ibu rumah tangga yang rajin bekerja. Setelah melahirkan 4 bulan yang lalu , Ni Luh Kasiantini sambil menjaga bayinya juga membuka usaha warung dirumahnya. Segala bahan kebutuhan sehari-hari disediakan seperti sembako,dan sayur mayur. Selain menjual aneka kebutuhan pokok, Ni Luh Kasiantini juga menjual makanan untuk babi seperti dedak gandum, dedak padi dan konsentrat. Dengan modal awal Rp.1.000.000,- Ni Luh Kasiantini memulai usahanya. Keuntungan yang diperoleh dalam satu hari bisa mencapai Rp.50.000,-. Keuntungan ini dipakai untuk membantu suaminya, I Komang Suwitra, yang mempunyai usaha dagang biji kakao, untuk memenuhi kebutuhan hidupnya dan juga untuk pendidikan 2 anaknya yang baru duduk dikelas 4 SD dan yang kedua baru TK sedangkan yang terakhir masih bayi 4 bulan. Ni Luh Kasiantini berharap dengan modal yang diperoleh dari Dinari, Ni Luh Kasiantini bisa mengembangkan usahanya menjadi lebih maju. Rumahnya dibangun ditanah sendiri dan bangunan yang cukup permanen. Biaya untuk kebutuhan sehari-hari bisa mencapai Rp.25.000,- perhari.

loans.use:
To add business capital

Menambah Modal Usaha

loans.name: Ni Ketut Sutiami

texts.id:
Because of high living cost to pay for expenses of 2 school aged children, Ni Ketut Sutiami forced herself to open a retail stall in her home. She is doing this, since she wants a better family life from her increased income. Previously Ni Ketut Sutiami only works as a tentant farmer. Ni Ketut Sutiami sells vegetable, light food, bread and drinks. With an initial capital of Rp 1,000,000 (about US$110), Ni Ketut Sutiami buys her items and vegetables from her customers. Ni Ketut Sutiami goes to the market from 4:00 AM to buy her retail items needs in the Morning Market in Negara city. Ni Ketut Sutiami opens her retail stall from 7:00 AM to 6:00 PM. Each day profit could reach up to Rp50,000 (US$5.50). This profit is used to help her husband I Made Rina who works as a tenant farmer, to pay living expenses and education expenses for their 2 children. First child is in 9th Grade, and the second in 5th grade. Capital loaned from Dinari would be used to complete facilities in retail stall. Ni Ketut Sutiami hopes that with Dinari's capital her business would expand, moves forward, and their lifes needs fulfilled.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Karena biaya hidup yang cukup berat karena harus menanggung dua anak yang masih sekolah, Ni Ketut Sutiami memberanikan diri untuk membuka usaha warung dirumahnya. Hal ini dilakukannya, karea ia ingin kehidupan keluarganya lebih baik dari peningkatan pendapatannya. Sebelumnya Ni Ketut Sutiami hanya bekerja sebagai petani. Ni Ketut Sutiami menjual sayur - mayur , makanan ringan, roti dan minuman. Dengan modal awal Rp.1.000.000,- Ni Ketut Sutiami membeli barang dagangan dan sayur mayur dari langganannya. Ni Ketut Sutiami pergi kepasar pada pukul 04.00 pagi untuk membeli keperluan warungnya di Pasar Pagi di kota Negara. Ni Ketut Sutiami mulai membuka warungnya dari jam 07.00 pagi sampai jam 18.00 sore hari. Keuntungan yang diperoleh satu hari mencapai Rp.50.000,- perhari. Keuntungan ini dipakai untuk membantu suaminya I Made Rina yang bekerja sebagai petani untuk memenuhi kebutuhan hidupnya dan juga pendidikan kedua anaknya . Anak yang pertama duduk dikelas 3 SMA dan yang kedua duduk di kelas 5 SD.Modal yang dipinjamn dari Dinari digunakan untuk melengkapai persediaan di warungnya. Ni Ketut Sutiami berharap dengan modal yang didapat dari Dinari usahanya akan lebih maju dan berkembang, dan kebutuhan hidupnya terpenuhi.

loans.use:
To add capital to complete facilities in retail stall

Menambah Modal usaha untuk melengkapi fasilitas warungnya

loans.name: Rugiye

texts.en:
Rugiya A. is a refugee from the Azerbaijan- Armenian conflict territory Gubadli region, situated in the western part of Azerbaijan.  She is 57 years old and a mother of 3 children.  She began her business with $300 in 2004. At first, she was selling children's clothing and earning little money. This money was enough for only some of her family's basic needs. She had difficulty in covering other family consumption needs for medication, clothes, school etc. 
 
She is busy with mobile industry goods, retail trade. She wants to improve her business and increase the number of her clients . Rugiye needs  $800 to expand her business, to open an area of private trade to sell her wholesale goods in the central market. She hopes to eventually  expand her business.
She thinks that this will improve the living conditions of his family. She will repay the loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her business, to sell her wholesale goods to private customers

payments.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business 22391

loans.name: Fadi

texts.en: Fadi sells Hubble Bubbles, otherwise known as 'narguileh' Lebanon. Fadi is a 37 year old bachelor who lives in Nabatieh, in the South of Lebanon.  Fadi has built a network of clients who frequently visit him . This will be the 7th time Fadi has taken a loan from Al Majmoua, meaning he has a long and solid history with the association.  Fadi is known to be a hardworking person, who has never been late in his payments. Fadi is an ambitious entrepreneur who wishes to vary his source of income.  He is determined to invest in the car sales business. His business plan is very clear and he wishes to go on in investing in flourishing businesses.

loans.use: To invest in a sales car business

loans.name: Habib

texts.en: Habib lives with his wife and their 2 children in Nabatieh, in south Lebanon. Habib is very proud of his wife being a teacher and he would also like his wife to be proud of him. He is therefore determined to invest more in his mobile phone store and to be a very successful businessman. He needs $1000 to buy enough phones and accessories to develop his business. Together they are striving to provide good living conditions for their beautiful family.

loans.use: To buy mobile phones and accessories

loans.name: Haidar

texts.en: Haidar is 32 years old and the father of 2 children. He lives in Nabatieh, in south Lebanon and earns a living by working in his barbershop. Haidar enjoys his job and likes being in contact with his clients who have become his friends. He decided to start selling perfumes, creams and other beauty products to extend his business services. He also needs new barber tools so he can work more efficiently. Haidar is always striving to enhance his business.

loans.use: To buy the needed tools and beauty products for his barber shop

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en: Hussein A. is a 37 year old father of 2 children. He lives in Nabatieh, in south Lebanon. Hussein is in the mobile phone business. He needs $1000 to buy new phones. Hussein does not only sell phones; he also repairs them. If you have a problem with your telephone you can be sure Hussein can fix it.

loans.use: To buy new mobile phones for his business

loans.name: Ramil

texts.en:
I. Ramil was born in the Azerbaijan- Armenian conflict territory the Fizuli region, situated in the western part of Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region. Right now he lives with his family in Sumgayit city. He is 29 years old, married and a father of 3 children. His father and mother live with him. His parents are old. Therefore he is the only breadwinner of his family. He started his business in 2004. He sells perfumes, creams, lotions, perfumes, shampoo. His friend helps him at this work. With this business he earns little money. The money is only enough for  some of his family's basic needs. 

He needs $700 to buy silver goods and merchandise in order to have a bigger inventory and be able to offer his clients a bigger variety and quality. He is able to support his family’s expenses with this income. He will repay the loan within 12 months. He believes that you will help him in this business.

loans.use: To buy silver goods and merchandise in order to have a bigger inventory and be able to offer his clients a bigger variety and quality

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Norwegian Microcredit LLC (Normicro) - Oct 24, 2008)
Correction due to underpayment for business 22396

loans.name: Hang

texts.en: The father was in an accident so now he can no longer work.The mother must work harder to support her family and take care of her husband. She got two loans to add to her capital to sell rice cakes and earned an extra profit of $ 19 in 3 months. Now she wants to borrow the 3rd loan of $ 75 to continue her business to support  5 members of her family. She will pay it back during 5 months.

loans.use: Sell rice cakes

loans.name: Hoa

texts.en: 4 members in this family work as day labourers and plant  green dragons, the youngest son is in the 10th class. They got their 1st loan to plant green dragons and their profit increased $ 44. Now they want to get the 2nd loan to continue to invest  in their green dragon and will pay back it during 5 months.

loans.use: Invest in green dragons

loans.name: Trang

texts.en: This family has 7 members : the grand father; the parents, who plant green dragons; and 4 children who are in school.They got their 1st loan for planting and their profit has increased $ 25 in a years Now they want to get the 2nd loanof  $ 75 to continue to invest. They will pay it back in the next 5 months.

loans.use: Invest green dragon

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius M. is a 43-year-old man, who is a practicing doctor. He is married and has three adult children. He lives in Kayole, an informal settlement within Nairobi, where he also runs his medical clinic. Apart from his family, he takes care of two children orphaned by HIV/AIDS.

Dr. M. began a clinic back in his rural home in 1996 using some of his own savings amounting to about Ksh. 70,000 (USD 1000), that he had put aside when he was still employed by the Kenyan government. By 1998, the clinic's business had grown tremendously, so that he had moved locations thrice, in order to accommodate the immense need for medical services.

Unfortunately in 1998, he encountered several difficulties when the landlord where his business was located increased the rent to four times higher; the rent shot from about US$ 570 to US$ 1715. He therefore found that due to this steep increase in overhead, he could no longer manage to pay the workers he had employed, let alone continue with the operations of the clinic. Apart from this, his clinic also suffered tremendously due to non-payment of medical bills, i.e., many patients he had admitted failed to remit payments. To further compound the problem, many of these patients were either relatives or neighbours from his home area, making it more difficult for him to reclaim payments, since culturally, it would seem very insensitive of him. By the year 2001, he had incurred a working loss of Ksh. 1.5 million, (US$ 21,430). This amount has not been paid to date.

In addition to these problems, he encountered another issue when he traveled to attend a seminar and was away for three months. Upon his return, he found that his staff had stolen and sold off most of the medical equipment he had acquired, and the clinic had actually been run down. This was a very difficult experience for him, therefore he decided to close what was remaining of the clinic, and he carried away the little furniture that was left. It is with this furniture that he decided to start off a small clinic within Kayole, an informal settlement within Nairobi.

The Exodus clinic is located in the Kayole area of Nairobi, in the middle of a low-income group of residents. The clinic is formally registered with the Ministry of Health in Kenya. Most of the patients that Dr. M. attends to are mothers and children, together with HIV/AIDS patients. His aim of setting up the clinic was to reach the less privileged in Kenyan society, by providing medical service that is affordable for them.

Dr. M. now intends to set apart a child welfare clinic within his premises, from where he will be in a better position to provide services related to the growth and well-being of children ages five years and below, from the Kayole area. From here he intends to provide vaccinations and health education for the parents, and he will also include family planning services. As an extension, he intends to provide home-based care, that is, door-to-door vaccination services, and generally attempt to raise the awareness of the community concerning the importance of vaccination for children.

Dr. M. is therefore requesting a loan amounting to US$ 950 with which he will be able to partition off a part of the treatment room, in order to create space for the child welfare clinic. The loan will also enable him to purchase furniture for his clinic, acquire an assortment of medical drugs, a scale for babies, surgical forceps and scissors. He will also purchase a small television set that will keep the children busy as they wait to receive treatment. He intends to repay the loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To purchase office and clinic furniture, medical drugs, baby weighing scale, assorted surgical forceps and scissors, and a small TV set

loans.name: Fridah

texts.en:
Fridah Wanjiku K. is a single lady of 21 years. Fridah resides in Mlolongo, a town located along the busy Nairobi-Mombasa highway. Though young compared to other businesswomen, Fridah has always been business-minded. In the year 2005, with an initial capital of Ksh 2000 (US$ 30) that she saved while employed at a Nairobi boutique, she teamed up with her cousin, Anne Wamaitha, and rented a stall in Mlolongo. Together they share the rent and Fridah deals in teen and children’s wear while her cousin deals in shoes.

Fridah says that she cannot complain about her business, since it has greatly improved and she is thankful that she began her business of selling clothes. With the holiday season approaching (November and December), there is a high demand for clothes and shoes as many families leave the Nairobi area and spend the holidays with their families in the rural areas. Clothes and shoes are usually bought as gifts, which are then shared with the members of the extended family during Christmas.

Fridah and her cousin are looking forward to this busy shopping season and Fridah is praying that a Kiva lender will respond to her request for a loan, to enable her increase her inventory and therefore, increase her sales. Fridah is requesting a loan of US$ 750 to help her in purchasing new children's wear, babies’ clothing, blankets, and plastic items such as cups, plates, etc. This new stock will greatly boost her business and also her income. The repayment period for this loan is 10 months.

loans.use: To purchase teen wear, children's and baby wear, blankets and assorted plastics and cutlery

loans.name: May

texts.en:
Babies, lots of babies. That’s what catches your eye when you enter May K.’s business. May has the Bulenga Clinic Maternity Home, and she is the chairperson for her lending group. May is 48 and married with four children of her own. She also cares for two orphans. She has been a mid-wife for 20 years and has operated her clinic for the same period.

May’s clinic serves an essential need in her community as health services are not within easy access to the very poor. She delivers an average of 20-24 babies per month, and the babies and their mothers stay for about two days. She has rooms and can care for up to five babies at a time.

May is currently in the process of building a new maternity home which she will own rather than rent. It will be more modern. With this loan she plans to buy more sheets for her business. May is a very kind, caring person whose heart is obviously in the right place.

loans.use: To buy more sheets for her maternity clinic.

loans.name: Hadijah

texts.en:
Hadijah N. is 35 and married with four children and two dependents. She sells lumber. In Uganda, lumber is generally rough sawn just on the outskirts of town and brought to the lumber ards by truck. Lumber is sold by small businesses. The sizes generally are: 2 x 4’s, posts and 1 x 10’s. With just those materials one can construct a small building with siding. 

Hadijah has been selling lumber for two years and has belonged to her lending group for  seven years. With her loan, Hadijah will expand her business by building up her inventory.

loans.use: To buy more lumber

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard K. is 26, single and takes care of three orphaned children. He has a strong entrepreneurial spirit. He owns a retail shop, is a property broker, and has a boda-boda business. Boda-boda are motorbikes, and the streets of Kampala are filled with matatoos (taxi vans) and boda-bodas. The word boda-boda comes from motorbikes that take people to the border, drop them off and another motorbike picks them up once they crossed the border, hence boda-boda. Plus it’s fun to say.

Richard has had his business for five years and has been with his lending group for three years. He will use his loan to buy some much needed parts for his boda-boda. He is very energetic and one day he hopes to his business will be successful enough to enable him to marry.

loans.use: To buy  parts for his boda boda

loans.name: Idahosa

texts.en: Mr. Idahosa O. is 48 years old, is married, and has six children.  He lives in Benin City in Edo State, where he has a pig farm. He spent three months learning pig rearing, and then he established his farm in 2004. He is requesting a loan of $800 to enable him to buy more pigs and feed for his farm. This will help him serve his customers better. He thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more pigs to raise and sell

loans.name: Nneka

texts.en: Mrs. Nneka H. is 26 years old and lives in Asaba town in Delta State. She is married and has three children. She learned the retail business from a friend, who taught her about it for two months, and she started her own store in 2004. She looks forward to the loan of $800 to buy more women's shoes and bags to sell. She has been with LAPO for two years now.

loans.use: To buy more women's shoes and bags for sale

loans.name: Anthonia

texts.en: Mrs. Anthonia O. is 54 years old, is married, and has seven children. She lives in Asaba town in Delta State, where she owns a restaurant selling all kinds of African dishes and drinks to people in her community. She learned the business from her sister and started her own restaurant in 1995. She is requesting a loan of $1,175 to buy a generator that would enable her to cool drinks and foodstuffs. She has been with LAPO for two years.

loans.use: To buy generator for cooling drinks	and foodstuffs

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Mrs. Victoria E. is a 46-year-old woman who lives in Asaba town in Delta State. She is married and has four children. She has been with LAPO for seven years and has been in business since 1996. She is requesting a loan of $625 to enable her to buy more foodstuffs to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Apolonia

texts.en: Mrs. Apolonia E. is a 46-year-old woman who lives in Asaba town in Delta State. She is married and has two children. She started her business in 1988. She is requesting a loan of $800 to buy more foodstuffs for her store. She has been with LAPO for five years as a leader of her union.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Mrs. Agnes O. is a 45-year-old woman who lives in Asaba, Delta State. She is married and has six children. She mills grains and sells provisions and drinks. She studied this business for two years before opening her store in 2003. She is requesting a loan of $800 to buy more provisions and drinks to sell. She is a LAPO member.

loans.use: To buy provisions and drinks to sell

loans.name: Anike

texts.en: Mrs. Anike D. is a 45-year-old woman who lives in Asaba, Delta State. She is married and has eight children. She sells provisions, foodstuffs, and drinks, She studied the business for three years before opening her store in 1975. She is requesting a loan of $800 to buy provisions, foodstuffs, and drinks to sell. She has been a member of LAPO for three years.

loans.use: To buy  provisions, drinks, and foodstuffs

loans.name: Sarita

texts.en: Mrs. Sarita M., 29, lives in Bholdhoka with her husband, Mr. Sagar M.. Most of the people in this region are involved in business professions. Mr. Sagar M. is a taxi driver. He drives a taxi in Kathmandu Valley. Mrs. M. opened a grocery shop two years ago. She sells different types of grocery goods in her shop. Due to a lack of money she cannot expand her business. So, she seeks a loan to buy necessary goods like noodles and biscuits to invest in her business.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods for her shop

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Patan Business and Professional Women - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Ejime

texts.en: Mrs. Ejime B. lives in Asaba, Delta State. She is 48 years old and is married with two children. She sells fish feed. She spent six months learning about this business, and she opened her business in 2006. She is requesting a loan of $800 to buy more fish feed to sell. She has been with LAPO for eight years now.

loans.use: To buy fish feed to sell

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen Ndegwa is 19 years old. He is a very active young man who finished secondary school last year with a grade point average of B+. After finishing school, Stephen decided not to be idle and hanging out with the wrong company. He was worried that without a job he would be influenced towards bad behavior, such as bhang smoking and drinking. Stephen says these activities are common to young men who are idle, due to lack of employment. Stephen reasoned with his mother and she was very happy that he showed interest in joining in her business.

Stephen’s mother has a big stall in Kitengela, where she does tailoring. She decided to partition off a section of her stall, where Stephen started selling school uniforms on her behalf. After a probationary period of eight months, his mother noticed that Stephen was a very good salesman and that he interacted with the customers well. His mother gave him a loan of Ksh 40,000 (US$ 570) so that he could purchase tailoring accessories and sell them in his section of their stall. He sold the entire inventory within one month and his mother was very impressed, especially when he immediately repaid half of the loan (Ksh 20,000). Stephen’s mother saw his determination and told him not to repay the outstanding balance of his loan, but rather to increase his stock for the business. This activity was all in August 2007, and since then his business has grown tremendously.

With the blessings of his mother, Ndumi Mutua, who has also benefited from a Kiva loan, Stephen would like Kiva to help him become a shining example to his fellow young men in Kitengela. He is therefore requesting a loan of US$ 750. With this loan Stephen will be able to purchase hooks, canvas, threads, materials for uniforms, buttons, and linings. These materials will greatly improve his business since customers will have access to a wide variety and they will save time and money. Normally, customers in Kitengela have to travel to Nairobi in order to buy school uniforms. Stephen intends to repay this loan within a period of 10 months.

loans.use: To purchase assorted tailoring accessories including lining, buttons, canvas, hooks, thread and school uniform materials

loans.name: Yawovi Francis

texts.en:
Mr. A. Yawovi Francis was born January 4, 1970 in Gati-Akpafo. He currently lives in Lome in the neighborhood Wuiti. He is a single father of one child of his own and one child of his sister's, who was left under his care. He is a photographer and would like to open a photo/video studio, however, his limited income hinders his endeavors to complete this desire. To make this idea a reality, he needs a loan of $1,000 to purchase the land for his studio and the necessary fitting-out. This would allow him to attract more clients with the goal of increasing his profits.

Translated from French by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

Mr A. Yawovi Francis est né le 4 Janvier 1970 à Gati – Akpafo. Il est actuellement à Lomé et plus précisément dans le quartier de Wuiti. Il est célibataire avec un enfant et un enfant autre de sa sœur est à sa charge. Il est photographe et veut ouvrir son studio de photo et vidéo mais ses maigres économies ne lui permet pas la réalisation de ce projet. Pour ce faire, il sollicite un crédit d’un montant de 1000$ pour la location d'un local, et acheter des nécessaires pour l'aménagement de son studio. Ceci lui permettra d'attirer plus de clientèle en vue d'accroître ses revenus.

loans.use: Opening a Photo and Video Studio

loans.name: Benedita

texts.en: Mrs. Benedita C. is 41 years old and lives in Asaba, Delta State. She is married and has five children. She is asking for a loan of $800 to enable her buy more yams to sell. She has been in this business since 2000.

loans.use: To buy more yams to sell

loans.name: Marie

texts.en:
Today a widow, S. Marie was born in 1971 in Benin. She currently lives with her three children in Lome, in the neighborhood Tokoin Lycee. She is a retailer of basic goods and necessities though she also has a general grocery store. A single mother, she is the sole provider for her children, but because their needs take priority, she often lacks the funds necessary to stock and supply her grocery store, which means she sometimes loses customers. She is asking for a loan of $400 to expand her business. With the loan, she will stock her store with sacks of rice, oil and other goods, because it will soon be time for the end-of-the-year festivals. This will allow her to increase her earnings, directly profiting her children and giving them a better future.

Translated from French by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

Veuve S. Marie est née en 1971 au Bénin. Elle vie actuellement à Lomé dans le quartier Tokoin Lycée avec ses trois (3) enfants. Elle est revendeuse des produits de premières nécessités et a également une boutique d’alimentation générale. Seule devant la charge des enfants elle souvent en manque de fonds de commerce pour alimenter sa boutique ce qui fait qu’elle perd à petit coup sa clientèle. Elle sollicite un crédit d’un montant de $400 pour agrandir la taille de son commerce. S’approvisionner en sacs de riz, d’huile et autres car c’est bientôt les fêtes de fin d’année. Ceci augmentera son revenu en vue d’un meilleur devenu de ses enfants.

loans.use: Supplying/stocking Her Grocery Store

loans.name: Nirmala

texts.en: Mrs. Nirmala M. lives in Kulashwor with her husband and two daughters. Kulashwor is a very busy business center located in Kathmandu Valley. Most of the people in this town are engaged in business. Mrs. M.'s husband works at Gutam Finance in Kulashwor. Her older daughter is studying in primary school and her younger daughter is in lower primary school. The income of her husband is not enough to cover the household expenses. So, two years ago Mrs. M. opened a grocery shop. Now she seeks a loan to invest in her shop to buy grocery goods.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods for her shop

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Patan Business and Professional Women - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Judith

texts.fr:
Mrs. Judith Q. was born on 5 May 1978 in Lomé. She was unable to continue her studies after the BEPC due to her parents' poverty, which led her to marry very early on. She has two (02) children. Her husband's job, a drink seller, has slowed down considerably, which makes things more difficult for the household. Very quickly, she started selling a maize paste called "Ablo" in the language Ewe. Her modest financial means are insufficient to purchase maize, wood, and sugar regularly. Thus, she is asking for a loan of $400 to be able to stock maize, wood, and sugar. This loan will allow her to strengthen her purchasing and selling power, and her income will increase to let her provide for the needs of her family and the education of her children.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer.

Mme Q. Judith est née le 05 mai 1978 à Lomé. Elle n’a pas pu continuer ses études après le BEPC à cause de la pauvreté des parents ; ce qui la poussé à se marier très tôt. Elle a deux (02) enfants. L’activité de son mari, débiteur de boisson, aujourd’hui a beaucoup ralenti ce qui fait que les problèmes du foyer s’accentuent. Très rapidement, elle se lance dans la vente de la pâte du maïs appelé « Ablo » en éwé. Ses petits moyens financiers ne suffisent pas pour acheter régulièrement le maïs, le bois, du sucre. Pour cela, elle désire un crédit de 400 dollars pour pouvoir faire les stocks de maïs, de bois, du sucre. Cet argent lui permettra d’augmenter son pouvoir d’achat et de vente et le revenu va accroître pour pouvoir subvenir aux problèmes de famille et scolarisation des enfants.

loans.use: To buy wood and stock maize (corn)

loans.name: Aastamaiya

texts.en: Mrs. Aastamaiya D., 44, lives in Chappagaun, a village famous for vegetable farming. She lives with her husband and two children. Her daughter is studying in grade 12 and her son is in grade 11. Her husband, Bhakta Lal D., is a carpenter and opened his furniture shop 6 years ago. He makes different varieties of furniture, such as beds, tables, and chairs. All the family's needs depend on the shop income. Therefore, Mrs. Aastamaiya seeks a loan to buy timber to meet the demand for the furniture.

loans.use: To buy timber to make furniture

loans.name: Ablavi

texts.fr:
Mrs. Ablavi T. was born in 1973 in Ahokpè. She currently lives in Lomé in the Tokoin Lycée area. She is married and has one (01) child, and also has two (02) of her sister's children in her care. Mrs. Ablavi T. is a dressmaker by profession and has 3 apprentices. In addition to her dressmaking, she sells beans. With the approaching festivals at the end of the year and her customers' demands, she wants to add the sale of loincloths to her business but she does not have the necessary funds. In order to realize this dream, which she holds very dear, she is asking for $1000 in financial help. This will also allow her to create a reliable stock of beans in order to better serve her clientele.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer.

Madame T. Ablavi est née en 1973 à Ahokpè. Elle vit présentement à Lomé dans le quartier Tokoin Lycée. Mariée et mère de un (01) enfant et deux (02) autres enfants de sa sœur sont à sa charge. Madame T. Ablavi est couturière de profession et a 3 apprenties. En plus de sa couture elle fait le commerce du haricot. A l’approche des fêtes de fin d’année et sur demande de sa clientèle et elle veut ajouter la vente des pagnes à son métier mais les fonds nécessaires lui manque. En vue de réaliser ce rêve qui lui tient trop à cœur, elle sollicite un apport financier de $1000. Ceci lui permettra aussi de faire un stockage consistant du haricot afin de mieux servir sa clientèle.

loans.use: To buy and sell loincloths and beans

loans.name: Amélie

texts.fr:
Mrs. Amélie G. was born on 5 October 1972 in Amégnra. She lives in Lomé, where she works as a seamstress. Unmarried with one (01) child, she abandoned her studies in primary school due to a lack of support, and began as an apprentice seamstress to be able to support herself. Today, she has mastered her profession, but does not have the necessary means to open a workshop, which means she works at her home. She is asking for a loan of $400 to buy sewing machines and outfit her workshop to attract more customers, since it will soon be festival season.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer.

Madame G. Amélie est née le 5 Octobre 1972 à Amégnra. Elle réside à Lomé où elle exerce son métier de couture. Célibataire avec un (01) enfant, elle a abandonné ses études dès les cours primaires faute de manque du support, et elle s’est lancée dans l’apprentissage de couture pour pouvoir se prendre en charge. Aujourd’hui, maîtresse de son métier, mais n’a pas les moyens nécessaires pour ouvrir un atelier ce qui fait qu’elle s’exerce à la maison. Elle sollicite un crédit d’un montant de $400 pour payer les machines à coudre et aménager son atelier pour attirer plus de clientèle car bientôt c’est la période des fêtes.

loans.use: To buy sewing machines

loans.name: Rogina

texts.en: Mrs. Rogina T. is a housewife who lives in Kulashwor, Kathmandu, in a family of four. She and her husband, Mr. Rabi T., and opened their grocery shop nine years ago. Her daughter and son are studying in primary school. During the month of October, the Nepalese observe two big festivals, Dashain and Tihar. During these festivals people buy many grocery items. This month is a great month for businesses, whether they are big or small. Mrs. Rogina T. is asking for her first loan so that she can invest in more varieties of grocery items in this season to meet the customers' demand.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods for the Dashain and Tihar festivals

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Patan Business and Professional Women - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Kossi

texts.fr:
Born on 31 December 1972 in Lomé, Mr. Kossi ATSU abandoned his secondary studies very early and began as an apprentice tailor for men's and women's clothing, due to his parents' lack of means. A widower with 6 people in his care, he has become a master tailor as a result of his efforts over the past 15 years. He supports his household alone with a small income. He has problems with his sewing and haberdashery equipment and would like to enlarge his workshop. Thus, he is asking for a loan of $800 to realize this project. Providing him this financial support will contribute to the improvement of Mr. Kossi ATSU's living conditions.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer.

Né le 31 décembre 1972 à Lomé, Mr ATSU Kossi a vite abandonné les bancs aux cours secondaires et s’est lancé dans l’apprentissage de couture homme dame à cause de manque de moyens des parents. Veuf et ayant 06 personnes à sa charge, il est devenu aujourd’hui maître tailleur résultats de ses efforts depuis 15 ans. Il est seul a supporté les charges avec un revenu très peu. Il a des problèmes de machines à coudre, de mercerie et veut élargir son atelier. Pour cela il désire un crédit de 800 dollars pour réaliser son projet. Lui accorder des concours financiers, c’est contribuer à améliorer les conditions de vie de Mr ATSU Kossi.

loans.use: To buy sewing equipment

loans.name: Kayissan

texts.fr:
Madam T. Kayissan was born on January 25, 1982 in Lomé. She is a married mother of two children and takes care of her sister's two children. She buys and sells groceries. Her income is too low to buy sufficient supplies for her shop, which has resulted in a loss of customers. Very ambitious, and wanting to be at the top of her trade, she is asking for a credit of $600 to build her business. This will allow her to re-stock her supplies and satisfy her customers on time.

Translated from French by Ivana Kostic, Kiva Volunteer.

Madame T. Kayissan est née le 25 Janvier 1982 à Lomé, mariée et mère de deux (02) enfants et à sa charge deux (02) de ses sœurs. Elle est revendeuse des produits d’Alimentation générale. Ses moyens sont très limités pour approvisionner sa boutique ce qui fait qu’elle perd sa clientèle car elle n’est pas en mesure de les satisfaire. Très ambitieuse, et voulant être à la hauteur de son activité, elle sollicite un crédit de $600 pour renforcer la capacité de ses activités. Ceci lui permettra d’approvisionner sa boutique et satisfaire sa clientèle à temps.

loans.use: Buying supplies for grocery store

loans.name: Akossiwa Antoinette

texts.fr:
Mrs A. Akossiwa Antoinette was born on April 04, 1982 in Vogan. She is a married mother of one child and she takes care of her sister's 2 children. She is a hairdresser and hair braider, however, she does not have the means to re-arrange her living room into a salon in order to attract more customers. Very concerned for her future and that of her children, she asks for a credit of $400 to renovate her living room, and sell braids and wigs. The realization of this project will enable her to attract more customers and increase her income.

Translated from French by Ivana Kostic, Kiva Volunteer.

Madame A. Akossiwa Antoinette est née le 04 Avril 1982 à Vogan. Elle est mariée et mère de (01) enfant et deux autres enfants de sa sœur sont à sa charge. Coiffeuse et Tresseuse de profession, elle n’a pas les moyens suffisant pour aménager son salon ce qui fait qu’elle n’a pas essai de clientèle. Très soucieuse de son avenir, et celui de ses enfants, elle sollicite un crédit de $400 pour réaménager son salon, vendre des mèches, tissage et perruques. La réalisation de ce projet lui permettra d’attirer plus de clientèle et augmentera ses revenus.

loans.use: Remodelling of living room for hair salon

loans.name: Ganga

texts.en: Mrs. Ganga D. lives in Chappagaun. To improve her standard of living, she opened a grocery shop 3 years ago. She sells different items, such as noodles, rice, and biscuits. The demand for grocery goods is increasing in that area, so she is requesting her first loan from Kiva. She seeks a loan to buy grocery goods to meet the demand. She is very grateful for your support. She will use her income to provide a better education for her children.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Patan Business and Professional Women - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
To reach Florence’s business, you must go off the paved road for several miles. You will come to a very rural village where life is very quiet and pastoral. Cicada’s are heard in the trees. There is a pace to the day that is slower than the city. As in all of Uganda, there is always a stream of people walking, walking, walking.

Florence has a produce hut where she buys in larger quantities than a normal produce stand, but has less variety. She sells Irish potatoes, sweet potatoes, and cassava. People arrive with small plastic bags and she counts and fills their orders.

She has been operating the produce hut for six years and has been in a lending group for eleven years. She is widowed and has two children. Florence will use her loan to increase her inventory and sales.

loans.use: To increase her inventory of Irish potatoes, sweet potatoes, and cassava.

loans.name: Komi Franck

texts.fr: Mr. S. Komi Franck was born on August 30th 1975 in Ahepe, but he lives in Lome in the Hountigome district.  He is married and has two children, and looks after two of his sister's children.  He is an electrician apprentice. Not having all the materials, he is limited in being able to make a living and works with his friends who can help provide some income to bring home.  He is tired of this situation but does not want to borrow from his friends, so he is requesting a loan of $1000 to buy his own materials and open his own workshop.

loans.use: Open an electrician workshop and purchase of materials

loans.name: Ishowori

texts.en: Mrs. Ishowori S., 50, lives in Kulashwor, Kathmandu, with her husband and a son. Her husband, Mr. Shyam Bahadur S., is a retired officer, and her son also has no work, so the condition of their family is very miserable. They can't even fulfill their basic needs. To overcome their problem they opened their grocery shop 2-3 months ago. All three members of her family equally contribute in that shop. They work hard to earn more. Because of the hard work, their family condition is improving. Now Mrs. S. is asking for a loan to buy grocery goods to invest in her shop.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods for her shop

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Patan Business and Professional Women - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Niminou

texts.fr:
Mr. O. Niminou is a traditional furnace maker in Gbadago.  He was born in Lome on June 3rd 1979.  He is married and has one child and has primary education.  His wife runs a small business of materials (cloth), but it is hard to meet all the demands of the family.  Having a good sense of entrepreneurship, he has decided to open his own business and needs a credit of $400 to get the stock for his trade.  This money will allow him to improve his family situation and ensure that his child can go to school. 

Fabriquant de fourneaux traditionnels à Gbadago, Mr O. Niminou est né à Lomé le 03 juin 1979. Marié et père d’un (01) enfant, il a vite quitté les bancs après ses études primaires. Sa femme exerce le petit commerce de tissus pagne mais difficilement il arrive  à répondre aux besoins familiaux. Ayant un bon esprit d’entreprise et de gestion, il s’efforce à rentabiliser un crédit de 400$ pouvant lui permettre de faire  le stock de tôles qui est son premier outil de travail . Cet argent lui procurera un revenu lui permettant d’améliorer le bien-être de la famille et assurer la scolarisation de ses enfants.

loans.use: Purchase work material

loans.name: Kossi Yawotchè

texts.fr: Mr. A. Kossi Yawotche was born on January 19th 1961 in Kouve, but currently lives in Lome, in the Hountigome district.  He is married and has four children.  His wife manages the home.  He is a collector of sport lottos, an activity without much future and generating little income.  He would like a credit of $400 to develop his own economic activity and help his wife with her business (selling ice cones).

loans.use: Business location purchase

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Throughout the countryside there are large structures of adobe brick stacked in “towers”, sometimes with a base of 15’x15’ and rising 10’to 12’, with a small tunnel in the bottom running all the way through the base. This is the oven to fire bricks. For three days a hot fire is placed in the tunnel, and at the end of the period all the bricks in the tower are fired and ready to sell.

Juliet is married with three children and for the past two years, she has been making adobe bricks for sale. It is relatively cheap to start this business, but very labor intensive. The right “earth” is needed, along with adobe molds and firewood for the fire. When it rains  the muddy earth is put it in the molds, then the molds are removed and the bricks are stacked iin a “tower” and fired for 3 days. 

Juliet will use her loan to start a second business. Poultry raising. She will buy 200 chicks to raise as boilers. The loan will enable her to feed them for two and half months, and then she can sell them at the market.

loans.use: To buy chicken feed for her new business

loans.name: Rehimatu

texts.en: Mrs. Rehimatu U. is a 38-year-old fashion designer who lives in Asaba, Delta State. She is married and has three children. She has seven years of experience in business and has been a member of LAPO for four years. She is in need of $400 to enable her buy more clothes to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Anne

texts.en:
Anne Wamaitha K. is a 26-year-old single lady. She is in the business of selling new shoes at Mlolongo town where she resides. She started her business in the year 2000 with capital of Ksh 15,000 (US$ 220), which she saved while under employment at a small retail shop in Rongai town from 1999 –2000.

Anne started selling her goods in an open-air space because she didn’t have a stall where she could sell. However, luck was on her side, and in the year 2005, Anne teamed up with her cousin Fridah Wanjiku, who is also requesting a loan from Kiva, and together, they rented a stall and agreed to share the rent. Anne deals in the sale of shoes and an assortment of other items, while her cousin deals in the sale of clothes, hence their businesses are complementary. During the holiday seasons like the upcoming month of December, the demand for clothes and shoes is always high because this is when many people buy such things as gifts for their families, both in urban and rural places.

Anne’s business has been growing because of the high population in her area, and she finds that she always runs out of stock due to the high demand for the items in her stall. She now needs to purchase a stock of men’s shoes, ladies’ shoes, children’s shoes, plastic items, cutlery, and also bedcovers. Anne is therefore requesting a loan of USD 750, with which to increase her inventory. With an increase in her stock, she will be able to increase her profit, resulting in more income. She also intends to employ an additional person to help her around the boutique. The repayment period for her loan will be 10 months.

loans.use: To purchase stock of assorted shoes, assorted plastic items, cutlery and bedcovers.

loans.name: Fofonè Emmanuel

texts.fr: Mr. K. Fofone Emmanuel was born on December 31st, 1976 in Agou; he lives in Lome in the Nakafu district.  He is single but is responsible for the three children of his sister and brother.  He is a re-salesman of cloth (tissues), which is a business that is proving successful.  With the end of year celebrations approaching, he wants to enhance his stock and buy new materials for women, but requires a loan of $600 in order to do this.

loans.use: Purchase and sale of clothing for women

loans.name: Fofo

texts.fr:
Mr. E. Fofo is the chief mechanic in Gbadabo. He was born in 1981 in Tabligbo.  He left a difficult family and has turned to individual entrepreneurship for income generation.  He became the chief mechanic four years ago and is well known around the area. He manages three other staff.  He has put in a big effort to open a workshop but he does not have the material to repair all kinds of cars.  He would like a credit of $800 to buy work materials (nails, hammers, vices...) and expand the workshop.  The financial assistance provided to this project will help support his family. Mr. Fofo is disciplined and will repay the credit in 12 months. 

Mr E. Fofo est chef mécanicien à Gbadago né en 1981 à Tabligbo. Sorti d’une famille misérable,  il est très tôt abandonné les bancs pour se lancer en apprentissage. Devenu maître mécanicien depuis quatre ans, il est célibataire et a à sa charge trois personnes. Il a fourni beaucoup d’efforts pour ouvrir un atelier mais il n’a pas assez de matériels pour réparer les motos de toutes sortes. Il voulait un crédit de $800 pour acheter de matériels de travail (clés, martaux,  tourne-vice …), élargir l’atelier. L’appui financier apporte à ce projet, augmentera se revenus afin de contribuer aux besoins de famille. Il prétend régler ce crédit en 12 mois

loans.use: Purchase of work material and tools

loans.name: Anne

texts.en:
Anne Wamaitha K. is a 26-year-old single lady. She is in the business of selling new shoes at Mlolongo town where she resides.  She started her business in the year 2000 with capital of Ksh 15,000 (USD 220), which she saved while under employment at a small retail shop in Rongai town from 1999 –2000.

Anne started selling her goods at an open air space because she didn’t have a stall where she could sell. However, luck was on her side, and in the year 2005, Anne teamed up with her cousin Fridah Wanjiku and together, they rented a stall and they agreed to share the rent.  Anne deals in the sale of shoes and an assortment of other items, while her cousin deals in the sale of clothes, hence their businesses are complementary.  During the holiday seasons like the upcoming month of December, the demand of clothes and shoes are always high because this is when many people buy things as gifts for their families, both in urban and rural places.

Anne’s business has been growing due to the high population in her area, and she finds that she always runs out of stock due to the high demand of the items in her stall.  She now needs to purchase stock of men’s shoes, ladies’ shoes, children’s shoes, plastic items, cutlery, and also bedcovers. Wamaitha is therefore requesting a loan of USD 775, with which to increase her inventory.  With an increase in her stock, she will be able to increase her profit, hence resulting in more income.  She also intends to employ an additional person to help her around the boutique. The repayment period for her loan will be 10 months.

loans.use: To purchase stock of assorted shoes, assorted plastic items, cutlery and bedcovers.

loans.name: Anne

texts.en:
Anne Wamaitha K. is a 26-year-old single lady. She is in the business of selling new shoes at Mlolongo town where she resides.  She started her business in the year 2000 with capital of Ksh 15,000 (USD 220), which she saved while under employment at a small retail shop in Rongai town from 1999 –2000.

Anne started selling her goods at an open air space because she didn’t have a stall where she could sell. However, luck was on her side, and in the year 2005, Anne teamed up with her cousin Fridah Wanjiku and together, they rented a stall and they agreed to share the rent.  Anne deals in the sale of shoes and an assortment of other items, while her cousin deals in the sale of clothes, hence their businesses are complementary.  During the holiday seasons like the upcoming month of December, the demand of clothes and shoes are always high because this is when many people buy things as gifts for their families, both in urban and rural places.

Anne’s business has been growing due to the high population in her area, and she finds that she always runs out of stock due to the high demand of the items in her stall.  She now needs to purchase stock of men’s shoes, ladies’ shoes, children’s shoes, plastic items, cutlery, and also bedcovers. Wamaitha is therefore requesting a loan of USD 775, with which to increase her inventory.  With an increase in her stock, she will be able to increase her profit, hence resulting in more income.  She also intends to employ an additional person to help her around the boutique. The repayment period for her loan will be 10 months.

loans.use: To purchase stock of assorted shoes, assorted plastic items, cutlery and bedcovers.

loans.name: Yao Messan

texts.fr:
Mr. Yao Messan G. was born on 14 December 1989 in Tchékpo. He is unmarried with two (02) people in his care. A painter by profession, he manages a store selling paints. He is very ambitious and wants to open his own store, given that this is a flourishing trade. He manages his business well. He is asking for a loan of $1000. This will increase his income and give him financial autonomy.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer.

Monsieur G. Yao Messan est né le 14 Décembre 1989 à Tchékpo, il est célibataire avec deux (02) personnes à sa charge. Il est peintre de formation, et gère une boutique de vente de peinture. Très ambitieux, il veut ouvrir sa propre boutique car c’est un commerce florissant. Il a une bonne gestion de son activité. Il sollicite un crédit de $1000. Ceci augmentera ses revenus et lui donnera une autonomie financière.

loans.use: To open a shop selling paints

loans.name: Dopé

texts.fr:
Mrs. Dopé K. was born on 3 June 1977 in Lomé. She runs a telephone booth. The income from the booth alone is not enough to meet her needs. She would like to add the sale of telephone cards and other basic need goods. Since her finances are unable to help her realize this project, she is asking for a loan of $1000.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer.

Madame K. Dopé est née le 3 Juin 1977 à Lomé. Elle détient une cabine téléphonique. Le seul revenu de la cabine ne suffit pas pour subvenir à ses besoins. Elle veut ajouter la vente des cartes de recharge et d’autres produits de premières nécessités. Ses économies ne pouvant l’aider à la réalisation de ce projet elle sollicite un apport financier de $1000.

loans.use: To buy and sell telephone recharge cards

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is a classy lady. She is 46, married and cares for four orphans. She owns the Maria Fashions Design, a tailoring business. She has been in business for 15 years and has been a member of her lending group for five years. Her shop is filled with her creations.
 
With her loan, she will purchase another sewing machine and more material. She currently owns a Butterfly, a Swan, and a Victoria sewing machine, all pedal-powered. 

She needs another sewing machine because she has just started a school for young girls where they can learn the trade. This is very important because a lot of young girls have to drop out of school to take care of ailing parents and siblings. Having a trade can make the difference between having a job or going hungry.

Agnes hopes to have ten machines one day. Once the girls learn the trade, they receive a certificate from a vocational trade school.  Agnes serves a very important service in the lives of young girls in her area.

loans.use: To buy another sewing machine to help start a sewing school for girls.

loans.name: Kossi

texts.fr:
Mr. Kossi A. was born on 17 July 1966 and lives in Lomé. He is married with six (06) children of his own, and also takes care of his older brother's two (02) children. After his secondary education, he started an apprenticeship as an auto mechanic. Currently he is a master mechanic and has complete command of his business, and his work is without reproach, which only serves to increase his clientele. To strengthen his business, he is asking for a loan of $1000, which he will use to build a garage.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer.

Monsieur A. Kossi est née le 17 Juillet 1966 et réside à Lomé, Il est marié et père de six (06) enfants et à sa charge deux (02) enfants de son grand frère. Après les études secondaires il entre en apprentissage de la mécanique auto. Aujourd’hui il est maître mécanicien et a une parfaite maîtrise de ses activités et ses prestations sont sans reproche, ce qui ne fait qu’augmenter sa clientèle. Pour renforcer ses activités, il sollicite un crédit de $1000 qui va lui servir de construire un garage.

loans.use: To build a garage

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is 43 and married with five children. Her business is a roadside produce stand. She smiles easily, has a wonderful sense of humor, and welcomes all who pass her stand, located in front of her home. She has had this stand for four years and has been a member of her lending group for ten years.

Today she is selling bunches of onions, cabbage, eggplant, chapatas, avocado, eggs and popcorn. With her loan, she will buy more produce for her stand and pay school fees for her children. Alice dreams of one day opening a retail shop.

loans.use: To buy more produce for her stand and to pay school fees

loans.name: Frederic

texts.fr:
Born on 27 April 1967 in Lomé, Mr. Frédéric K. is a reseller of coal in Gbadago. Unmarried, he has one (01) child in his care. Coming from a destitute family, he was unable to go to school because of a lack of means; thus, he began a small business selling coal about 10 years ago. He has trouble buying bags of coal, so he is asking for a loan of $400 to increase his business and meet the needs of his family. He intends to repay this loan in 12 months without problems. This amount will allow him to restart some other income-generating activities.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer.

Né le 27 Avril 1967 à Lomé, Mr K. Frédéric est un revendeur de charbon à Gbadago. Célibataire, il a un (01) enfant à sa charge. Issu d’une famille misérable, il n’a pas pu fréquenter à cause de manque de moyen ; ce qui a fait que très tôt il a commencé le petit commerce de charbon ça fait 10 ans environ. Il a de la peine à acheter des sacs de charbon donc il sollicite un crédit de 400$ pour relever son commerce et subvenir aux besoins de la famille. Il compte rembourser ce crédit en 12 mois sans problème. Cette somme lui permettra de redemarrer d’autres activités génératrices de revenus.

loans.use: To stock coal

loans.name: Zakonome

texts.fr:
At 44 years of age, Mrs. Zakonome M. lives in Agoè Adjorigba. She is a widow with four (04) children. Her late husband did not leave her much with which to take care of her children. She runs a general food store. Not having any other sources of income, she is constantly faced with stock shortages, a situation which significantly decreases her clientele as well as her income. Worried about the future of her children, she is asking for a loan of $1000 to stock her store and establish a regular clientele.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer.

Agée de 44 ans, Madame M. Zakonome, résident à Agoè Adjorigba. Elle est veuve avec quatre (04) enfants. Son défunt mari n’a pas laissé grand-chose pour qu’elle s’occupe de ses enfants. Elle détient une boutique de vente d’alimentation générale. N’ayant pas d’autres sources de revenus, elle est tout le temps confronté à de rupture de stock ce qui fait baisser considérablement sa clientèle ainsi que ses revenus. Soucieuse de l’avenir de ses progénitures, elle sollicite un montant de $1000 pour approvisionne sa boutique et fidéliser sa clientèle.

loans.use: To stock her store with general foodstuffs

loans.name: Brigitte

texts.fr:
At 47 years of age, Mrs. Brigitte A. lives in Lomé. She is married and has two children. Her husband, a primary school teacher, does not earn enough to meet the needs of the family. To help him out, Mrs. Brigitte A. entered the general food business, which has done well, since she is the sole seller in the area. Given her meager finances, she is unable to meet the demands of her customers and risks losing them. She would like to open a large store where one can find all sorts of goods, but sadly, she lacks the means to do so. She is asking for a loan of $1000.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer.

Agée de 47 ans, Madame A. Brigitte résident Lomé. Elle est mariée et mère de deux enfants. Son mari un Instituteur n’a pas de grand revenu pour subvenir aux besoins de sa famille. Pour l’aider, Mme A. Brigitte s’est lancé dans le commerce d’alimentation générale, un commerce qui lui réussi bien car elle est la seule dans le quartier. Devant ses maigres économies, elle n’arrive pas à être à la hauteur de sa clientèle et risque de les perdre. Elle veut ouvrir une grande boutique où on peut trouver toutes sortes de choses mais les moyens lui manquent cruellement. Elle sollicite un crédit de $1000.

loans.use: To open a general food store

loans.name: Egnonam

texts.fr:
At the age of 29, Mrs. Egnonam O. is married and has three (03) children. She did not have the chance to go to school because her parents did not understand the need to educate a female child. Very quickly, she became an apprentice hairstylist (hair braiding). She opened a hair salon for braiding, and also sells hair, weaves, and wigs. Her mastery of the craft has given her a large clientele. At the end of this year, she wants to redo and outfit her salon in order to attract more customers, but her current means are lacking. She is asking for a loan of $300.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer.

A l’âge de 29 ans, Madame O. Egnonam est mariée et mère de trois (03) enfants. Elle n’a pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école car ses parents n’ont pas vite compris la nécessité de la scolarisation d’une fille. Très vite elle s’est lancée dans l’apprentissage de la coiffure (la tresse). Elle a ouvert un salon de coiffure tresse elle vend aussi les mèches, tissage, perruque. Maîtrisant bien son métier, ce qui lui confère une grande clientèle. A cette fin d’année, elle veut aménager et bien équiper son salon afin d’attirer plus de clientèle mais les moyens lui manques. Elle sollicite un crédit d’un montant de $300.

loans.use: To buy and sell hair, weaves, and wigs

loans.name: Anani

texts.fr:
Mr. Anani D. was born in 1979 in Notsè. He is married with one child and two other children of a brother are also his dependents. He is a retailer and has a store selling cement. Because of customer demand, he would like to add other constuction materials and hardware to his inventory, but he lacks capital. He is requesting a loan in the amount of US$ 1000.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Monsieur D. Anani est né en 1979 à Notsè. Marié avec un enfant, et deux (02) autres enfants de son frère sont à sa charge. Il est commerçant et a un magasin de vente de ciment. Sur la demande de sa clientèle, il veut ajouter d’autres matériels de construction et la quincaillerie mais les moyens lui manquent. Il sollicite un crédit d’un montant de $1000.

loans.use:
purchase and resale of building materials and hardware

Achat et vente de matériel de construction et quincaillerie

loans.name: Soedjodo

texts.fr:
Mr. Soedjodo K. is a master carpenter in Gbadago, Togo. Born on Nov. 28, 1980 in Vogan, Togo, he is married and father of one child. After his primary schooling, he was not able to remain in school because of his parents' poverty, and this pushed him to pursue an apprenticeship. He has now been working in his trade for five years. An upstanding and creative man and good at managing his business, he would like to produce furniture of excellent quality for sale. For that reason, he is requesting a loan of US$ 1000 so that he can purchase wood, machines for his workshop (lathe, plane, table saw, etc.) which will allow him to increase his income and better support his family since his wife does not work outside the home and thus has no income to add to his.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Mr K. Soedjodo est un chef menuisier à Gbadago. Né le 28 Novembre 1980 à Vogan, il est marié et père d’un (01) enfant. Après ses études primaires il n’a pas pu continué les études faute de la pauvreté des parents, ce qui l’a poussé à aller en apprentissage. Ça fait déjà 5 ans qu’il exerce ce métier. Ayant une bonne moralité, un esprit de créativité et de gestion, il veut nourrir son atelier en fabricant des meubles de qualité. Pour cela il sollicite un crédit de 1000$ pour faire le stock de bois, acheter des machines de travail (rebobineur, épulcheur, scie), ce qui lui permettra d’augmenter ses revenus et subvenir aux problèmes de foyer, sa femme étant une ménagère.

loans.use:
purchase of wood and machines for his carpentry work

Achat de bois et machines de travail

loans.name: Khodr

texts.en: Khodr is 27 years old and lives in Nabatieh, south of Lebanon. Khodr earns a living driving a mini-van. He transports people from Nabatieh to Saida or Beirut every day. This is the second time Khodr has requested a loan from The Lebanese Association for Development - Al Majmoua. He needs this loan in order to buy furniture for his home. This young man is determined to make it on his own and to make his parents proud of him being a self made man. Khodr doesn't only think of himself but is very determined to assist his parents in any way he can.

loans.use: To buy furniture for his home

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Abdoul Rahman

texts.fr:
Mr. Abdoul Rahman D. was born in 1974 in Sokodé and lives in Lomé. His wife is a bicycle/motorbike mechanic. They have two children and are also raising his big sister's three children. After his secondary schooling, he began an apprenticeship and now he is a master mechanic. He is completely at ease in his chosen trade and charges appropriately for his services, which has allowed him to expand his clientele with ease. To boost his business and permit him to acquire modern tools, Mr. D. is requesting a loan of US$ 1000.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Monsieur D. Abdoul Rahman est né en 1974 à Sokodé, résident à Lomé, il est marié à une femme mécanicienne à 2 roues et père de (02) enfants et trois (03) autres enfants de sa grande sœur sont à sa charge. Après les études secondaires , il entre en apprentissage. Aujourd’hui il est maître mécanicien. Il a une parfaite maîtrise de ses activités et ses prestations sont sans reproche, ce qui ne fait qu’augmenter sa clientèle. Pour renforcer son activité et acquérir d'autres outils moderne, Monsieur D. solliciter un crédit de 1000$.

loans.use:
repairing his workshop facility and purchasing modern tools

Aménagement de son atelier et achat des outils moderne

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her vegetable-selling business

loans.name: Yao

texts.fr:
Married and father of one child, Mr. Yao K. is a master metal worker in Gbadago. He was born on July 21, 1974 in Kpalimé and is responsible for two dependents besides his immediate family. Born into a very poor family, he had to leave school after 6th grade and decided to begin an apprenticeship. After about 8 years he became a master at his trade and tried his best to figure out how to get a workshop. Since he has not managed to find a way for his wife to engage in retail business, he is the sole breadwinner for his family. He encounters many difficulties in his work, such as lack of the necessary machines, no way to fix up his workshop, and even lack of metal to work with. These problems have made him decide to ask for a loan of US$ 400 for his business. This will allow him to expand his business activities into other spheres and thus better support his family by increasing his income.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Marié et père d’un (01) enfant, Mr K. Yao est un chef tôlier à Gbadago. Il est né le 21 Juillet 1974 à Kpalimé et a deux (02) autres personnes à charge. Issu d’une famille très pauvre, il a vite cessé les bancs en classe de quatrième et opte pour l’apprentissage. Devenu chef tôlier apres environ 8 ans, il a cassé de tête pour avoir un atelier. N’ayant pas trouvé de moyen pour sa femme afin de faire le commerce, il est seul face aux dépenses de la famille. Il rencontre beaucoup de difficultés dans ses activités tels que le manque de machines nécessaires, amélioration de l’atelier, les tôles. Ce qui le pousse à faire une demande de $400 pour son projet; ce qui lui permettra de se lancer aussi dans d’autres activités et répondre aux besoins de la famille et augmenter ses revenus.

loans.use:
purchase of raw materials

Achat de matieres premieres

loans.name: Azianle

texts.fr:
Mr. Azianle S. was born on April 25, 1978 in Lomé, Togo in the neighborhood called Agoè. He is married and father of three children. Because he could not pay school fees, he stopped after primary school and learned bicycle/motorcycle mechanics. The vast experience that he has in his trade plus the reasonable prices he charges his customers make him a mechanic who is esteemed by all. He is looking for funding to improve his inventory of parts so that he will always have on hand what he needs to do a job. For this reason, he is requesting a loan of US$ 300 which will allow him to stock spare parts that he can then also sell to his customers.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Monsieur S. Azianle est né le 25 Août 1978 à Lomé, dans le quartier d’Agoè. Il est marié et père de (03) enfants. Faut de moyens fianciers, il a arrêté ses études au cours primaire pour apprendre la mécanique à 2 roues. La grande expérience qu’il a acquise dans ce métier et la qualité de ses prestations font de lui un bon mécanicien apprécié par tous. Il recherche les moyens pour renforcer son équipement et disposer permanemment du matériel de travail.
